Cary,
I handled this sword when it was in Sotheby's years ago, it didn't sell.
Also I have had a rush of brains to the head and used the Token Bijutsu
index that I compiled, the blade is illustrated in #16.
Regards,
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Cary Condell" <condell@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, June 24, 2003 7:46 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Chikamura tatematsuru (saiba Juto)


: Alan,
: Quite so.
: If we are speaking about the same piece.
: The one I bought and sold was designated
: in Juyo Token session 26.
: In the Juyo zufu index it includes saiba in parenthesis.
: It was sanji mei: Chikamura Jo (agaru).
: In this case the third character would be
: construed to read tatematsuru (to offer
: as a presentation to the Emperor).
: I would have to recheck the Jufu page
: to see if there is a mention of the
: Mune character preexisting before Chika.
: If so it would have read:
: Munechika Murakami.
: Nonetheless your explanation is rational
: and is consistent with my memory.
:
: The basic point of my post was that saiba
: will pass Juyo providing it has a signature
: which is of supreme historical significance
: as reference material.
: This qualified under the "special circumstances" criteria.
:
: Regards,
: Cary Condell
:
: Condell & Co., Ltd.
: P.O. Box 590115
: San Francisco, CA 94159
:
: Tel. 415-751-3784
:
: condell@...
: http://www.ikkyudo.com
:
:
:
: alan bale wrote:
: > Cary,
: > I think you are mistaken, it was not signed Chikamura Murakami but
signed
: > with 3 kanji: 'chika', 'mura' & 'kami' or 'tatematsuru' and read
'Chikamura
: > Tatematsuru', when the 'Mune' was added at the front it became
'Munechika
: > Murakami' and the faker then a Munechika blade connected with the
Murakami
: > family.
: > Alan
: >
: > ----- Original Message -----
: > From: "Cary Condell" <condell@...>
: > To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
: > Sent: Tuesday, June 24, 2003 11:47 AM
: > Subject: [nihontostudy] Chikamura tatematsuru (saiba Juto)
: >
: >
: > : Alan,
: > : You are correct.
: > : I handled that sword about 10+ yrs. ago.
: > : It was designated Juyo Token while in the possession
: > : of a U.S. collector. The sayagaki by Homma sensei stated
: > : explicitly that the sword was saiba but because of it's
: > : extreme importance as reference material was granted Juyo status.
: > : The only other extant example being in the
: > : Imperial Household Collection (Gyobutsu).
: > : It was sold to a Japanese dealer who understood its importance.
: > : P.S. It was signed Chikamura Murakami.
: > : The Murakami was not added later, but is read as tatematsuru.
: > :
: > : Regards,
: > : Cary Condell
: > :
: > : Condell & Co., Ltd.
: > : P.O. Box 590115
: > : San Francisco, CA 94159
: > :
: > : Tel. 415-751-3784
: > :
: > : condell@...
: > : http://www.ikkyudo.com
: > :
: > : alan bale wrote:
: > : > Re retempered blades getting papers, there is at least one Juyo
saiba
: > blade,
: > : > it is signed 'Chikamura Tatematsuru', its existence proved that the
: > famous
: > : > Sanjo Munechika blade signed 'Munechika Murakami' was made by his
pupil
: > : > Chikamura and had the 'mune' added later. 'kami' and 'tatematsuru'
being
: > the
: > : > same kanji.
: > : >
: > :
: > :
: > : > Alan
: > : >
: > : > ----- Original Message -----
: > : > From: "David Zincavage" <jdz@...>
: > : > To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
: > : > Sent: Tuesday, June 24, 2003 5:58 AM

: > : >
: > : >
: > : > : As a matter of fact, the older and wiser crowd at Cary's study
group
: > were
: > : > tossing the term around about a Kamakura blade.  I wanted to
inquire,
: > but
: > : > the discussion moved on, and I didn't get a chance.  I made a note
of
: > the
: > : > term to look it up, and found Hawley's definition, which applied to
a
: > sword
: > : > I have at home.
: > : > :
: > : > : I think the definition you have provided is more likely what Cary
and
: > the
: > : > gang were talking about, though obviously odd in the case of such an
old
: > : > sword.  Thanks for the information.
: > : > :
